729478f.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729478f.text:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street and Kissell
Avenue, showing a broac view of the Sailors' Snag Harbor.
E. T. Clegs  about 188O'e aFTw. Iv92
729478f.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY

729459f-a.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729459f-a.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY

729461f-a.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729461f-a.text:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street
and Kissel Avenue. The three views show the ruins of the Home for
Sailors' Orphans, within, the grounds of Sailors' Snug Harbor.
The actual location of the Home was on the east side of Kissel
Avenue, about 175 yards north of Castleton Avenue, at the south
end of the Harbor grounds. Kissel Avenue can be seen in views
2 and 3; in the backgrodnd of view 1 appears the Harbor hospital.
June 30, 1927
Viewa 1, 2, 3
P. L. Sperr
729461f-a.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY

729460f-b.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729460f-b.text:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street
and Kissel Avenue. Shown are views of the corn field and
oreek on the grounds of Sailors' Snug Harbor. In the background
are the stacks of the Edison electric plant, on Richmond Terrsce
and Bard Avenue.
View 1: 1937
Views 2,3: 1938
P. L. Sperr
729460f-b.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY

729462f-b.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729462f-b.text:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street and
Eissel Avenue. Shown are two buildings and a summer playhouse
of the Home for Sailors' Orphans, part of Sailors' Snug Harbor.
The orphans' home is located on the east side of Kissel Avenue,
slightly north of Castleton Avenue. The buildings were later
demolished.
View 1: October 21, 1925
View 2: January, 1927
View 3: June 30, 1927
P. L. Sperr
729462f-b.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY

729463f-a.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729463f-a.text:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street and
Kissel Avenue. Shown is the Main Building of Sailors' Snug
Harbor, the home for destitue seamen. Tho Warbor was founded
in 1801 by the will of Captain Robert Richard Randall and the
asylum was opened in August, 1933. It occupies many acres of
land and cortains over fifty buildings.
About 1905
By Mulford Simonson
From Staten Island Museum Collection through P. L. Sperr
(2)
The hospital of Sailors' Snug Harbor, seen from
Henderson Avenue.
May 28, 1926
P. L. Sperr
729463f-a.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY

729477f-b.title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Tysen Street
729477f-b.text:
806 Richmmond Terrace, adjoining the S.E. corner
of Tysen Street, showing the "Stone Jug" built about 1770
by Captain JJohn Neville. This was at one time the home of
Judge Jacob Tysen. See also 'Legands.,Stories and Folklore
of O16 Staten Island by Hines and Davis, p. 30.
1924
L. Sperr
(2)
The same, at a later date. It appears in Bromley's
1917 Atlas as the Knickerbocker Hotel.
JM1Y 7, 19N2
P. L. Sperr
93)
An additional view seen from the opposite directiion.
July 7, 1932
P. L. Sperr
729477f-b.folder: Richmond Terrace & Tysen Street, Staten Island, NY
